title: About Me
text: Hello, I am Lexi! I am currently a student at Georgetown College majoring in marketing and minoring in Computer Science. I am currently a senior, and plan to graduate this December of 2023.

title: About Me
text:
Early/ Present Life

I am from a small town in Mt. Washington, Kentucky which is about 30 minutes away from Louisville. Throughout my younger years all the way up to college I played basketball which constantly kept me busy. Growing up I have lived in Mt Washington with my mom, dad and my sister. My sister is two years older than me and just recently got married in September. I also have a cat named Binx. I got him about two years ago from the Lexington Humane Society. In my free time I enjoy spending time with my friends and family, shopping, and going on walks.

title: About Me
text:
Future Life
After I graduate Georgeotwn College I plan on pursuing a job in sales. Preferably I would like to do something in the medical sales field. Although this is something I am very interested in now, I did not always know that was the path I wanted to take. Going into college I was unsure which route I wanted to pursue, but after taking some classes and experiencing new things marketing began to spark my interest.

title: Articles
text: The first two articles on this site are here to demonstrate how to properly solve two problems from the Eloquent Javascript book. These problems include the Math.min Function and Recursion. The third article explains the major enhancement I made to my website and how I was able to get it to work effectively.

title: Major Enhancement
text: The major enhancement I made was to the navbar on my website. I was able to change the background color, the style of the text, the color of the font when hovering over the headers, and made a dropdown menu for articles and blog. The image below shows the enhancement to my navbar.

title: Major Enhancement
Major Enhancement
Major Enhancement
text:
Navbar Drop Down

In order to add the drop down to the articles and blog I had to add some things to my _quarto.yml folder. The code is below.
website:
  title: "Lexi Taylor's Website"
  site-path: "/personal-lexi-taylor/"
  navbar:
    tools:
    left:
      - href: index.qmd
        text: Home
      - href: about.qmd
        text: About
      - text: Articles
        menu:
          - href: articles/index.qmd
            text: "Articles" 
          - href: articles/article_01.qmd
            text: "Minimum Function"
          - href: articles/article_02.qmd
            text: "Recursion" 
          - href: articles/article_03.qmd
            text: "Major Enhancement"
      - text: Blog
        menu:
          - href: posts/index.qmd
            text: "Blog" 
          - href: posts/2023-11-11-college-work
            text: "Navigating the Transition from College to Work"
          - href: posts/2023-11-17-animals-happiness
            text: "The Benefits of Animals in Your Life" 
          - href: posts/2023-11-17-essay-modification
            text: "Essay Modification"
          - href: posts/2023-11-17-life-work
            text: "Finding Balance Between Life and Work"
          - href: posts/2023-11-17-minor-enhancement
            text: "Minor Enhancement"
I added the text as Articles and Blog to the menu in my code to start the process of the dropdown. I then added the link and text to both the Articles and Blog headers. By doing this, each header has a drop down that has the title of each article and blog that you can click on. When learning how to add drop downs to the navbar I referred to the Github page below from the Quarto Website.

    
      Github!

title: Minor Enhancement
text: The minor enhancement that I made was to the Home page of my website. On the home page I added two clickable icons that take you to my GitHub and LinkedIn pages.

title: Minor Enhancement
text: The minor enhancement that I made was to the Home page of my website. On the home page I added two clickable icons that take you to my GitHub and LinkedIn pages.

title: Minor Enhancement
text:
What It Looks Like

As you can see in the image below, under the “Welcome!” there are two icons that can be clicked on.

title: Minor Enhancement
text:
How I Did It

When making my enhancement I reffered back to the Quarto website here. This website shows how to get these tools on the navbar. I wanted to take a different approach by adding these tools to my home page instead. I provided the code below that I used to do this.
---
title: "Welcome!"
format:
  html:
    page-layout: full
about:
  id: about
  links:
    - icon: clipboard-data
      text: LinkedIn
      href: "https://linkedin.com/in/alexis-taylor-b41a90293"
    - icon: github
      text: GitHub
      href: "https://github.com/lexitaylor5"
---
The code contains two links that both contain an icon, text, and an href. The setup of these links is what makes them two clickable icons on my home page.

title: Small Programming Task
text:
On the sidebar of my website, I added a Georgetown logo to the top of it. I have provided the code below on how I did this.
  sidebar:

    - id: none
      style: "docked"
      background: light
      logo: images/gclogo.jpg
      pinned: true 
      align: center
      collapse-level: 2
      contents:
        - section: "Articles"
          href: articles/index.qmd
          contents: 
            - text: "Minimum Function"
              href:  articles/article_01.qmd
            - text: "Recursion"
              href:  articles/article_02.qmd
            - text: "Major Enhancement"
              href:  articles/article_03.qmd
        - section: "Posts"
          href: posts/index.qmd
          contents: "posts/*/*.qmd"
          sort:
            - "date desc"
In my _quarto.yml in the sidebar part of my code I added a section called logo. I then inserted the image name into that section which placed the logo on the top left of my website. I referenced this link here

title: Small Programming Task
text:
Adding Buttons

I also decided to add buttons that are clickable and will take you to different links I have on my website. Instead of the clickable links looking like this: here
I made them look like this:   Click Here!  
The button helps make my website look more appealing and also stands out more compared to the hyperlink.

title: Minimum Function
text:
Below I have described a solution to the Minimum problem in Chapter 3 of the Eloquent Javascript book.
The problem is described in full if you click “Here” on the button below:

    
      Here!
    


Minimum
The previous chapter introduced the standard function Math.min that returns its smallest argument. We can build something like that now. Write a function min that takes two arguments and returns their minimum.
If you have trouble putting braces and parentheses in the right place to get a valid function definition, start by copying one of the examples in this chapter and modifying it.
A function may contain multiple return statements.

In the remainder of the article I have provided a detailed explanation of the solution-code.

title: Minimum Function
text:
Below I have described a solution to the Minimum problem in Chapter 3 of the Eloquent Javascript book.
The problem is described in full if you click “Here” on the button below:

    
      Here!
    


Minimum
The previous chapter introduced the standard function Math.min that returns its smallest argument. We can build something like that now. Write a function min that takes two arguments and returns their minimum.
If you have trouble putting braces and parentheses in the right place to get a valid function definition, start by copying one of the examples in this chapter and modifying it.
A function may contain multiple return statements.

In the remainder of the article I have provided a detailed explanation of the solution-code.

title: Minimum Function
Minimum Function
Minimum Function
text:
Test the Code
console.log(Math.min(0, 10));
console.log(Math.min(0, -10));
 0
-10
These lines of code are used to test the function that was made.
The first console.log line calls Math.min with the arguments 0 and 10. Since 0 is the minimum value, it should be printed out to the console.
The next console.log line calls Math.min with arguments 0 and -10. Since -10 is the minimum value, it should be printed out to the console.

title: Recursion Function
text:
Below I have described a solution to the Recursion problem in Chapter 3 of the Eloquent Javascript book.
The problem is described in full when you click on the button below:

    
      Click Here!
    


Recursion
We’ve seen that % (the remainder operator) can be used to test whether a number is even or odd by using % 2 to see whether it’s divisible by two. Here’s another way to define whether a positive whole number is even or odd:
Zero is even.
One is odd.
For any other number N, its evenness is the same as N - 2.
Define a recursive function isEven corresponding to this description. The function should accept a single parameter (a positive, whole number) and return a Boolean.
Test it on 50 and 75. See how it behaves on -1. Why? Can you think of a way to fix this?
Your function will likely look somewhat similar to the inner find function in the recursive findSolution example in this chapter, with an if/else if/else chain that tests which of the three cases applies. The final else, corresponding to the third case, makes the recursive call. Each of the branches should contain a return statement or in some other way arrange for a specific value to be returned.
When given a negative number, the function will recurse again and again, passing itself an ever more negative number, thus getting further and further away from returning a result. It will eventually run out of stack space and abort.

In the remainder of the article I have provided a detailed explanation of the solution-code.

title: Recursion Function
text:
Below I have described a solution to the Recursion problem in Chapter 3 of the Eloquent Javascript book.
The problem is described in full when you click on the button below:

    
      Click Here!
    


Recursion
We’ve seen that % (the remainder operator) can be used to test whether a number is even or odd by using % 2 to see whether it’s divisible by two. Here’s another way to define whether a positive whole number is even or odd:
Zero is even.
One is odd.
For any other number N, its evenness is the same as N - 2.
Define a recursive function isEven corresponding to this description. The function should accept a single parameter (a positive, whole number) and return a Boolean.
Test it on 50 and 75. See how it behaves on -1. Why? Can you think of a way to fix this?
Your function will likely look somewhat similar to the inner find function in the recursive findSolution example in this chapter, with an if/else if/else chain that tests which of the three cases applies. The final else, corresponding to the third case, makes the recursive call. Each of the branches should contain a return statement or in some other way arrange for a specific value to be returned.
When given a negative number, the function will recurse again and again, passing itself an ever more negative number, thus getting further and further away from returning a result. It will eventually run out of stack space and abort.

In the remainder of the article I have provided a detailed explanation of the solution-code.

title: Recursion Function
Recursion Function
Recursion Function
text:
Test the Code
console.log(isEven(50));
console.log(isEven(75));
console.log(isEven(-1));
true
false
false
These lines of code are used to test the function that was made.
Since 50 is an even number, the console should print true.
Since 75 is an odd number, the console should print out false.
Since 1 is not an even number, the console should print out false.
